explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is 62degC (ICSC (1999)), which is classified into Category 4.

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 190degC (ICSC, 1999).

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classified into Class 9 (UN#1990) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 1,500mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 1,300mg/kg (SIDS (1996)), 1,292mg/kg, 1,502mg/kg, 2,279mg/kg, 2,400mg/kg and 2,850mg/kg (DFGOT Vol.17 (2002)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Classification not possible because the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) value of >1,250mg/kg (SIDS (1996)) is not a definitive value.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests evaluated according to the Draize scheme (CERI Hazard Data 99-21 (2000)): "Moderate irritation." Also based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (DFGOT Vol.17 (2002)): "moderately irritating." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (though these results are those of 24 hour application).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (DFGOT Vol.17 (2002)): "slightly irritative."

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the description in the report on guinea pig skin sensitization tests evaluated in accordance with Draize, Maximization and FCA schemes (DFGOT Vol.17 (2002)): "Positive results were obtained in all three schemes." Also based on the description in the report on epidemiological studies of human exposure (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)): "Patch tests on human volunteers gave positive results."

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible in the absence of data on in vivo mutagenicity/genotoxicity tests. Also benzaldehyde has been known to possess only a low genotoxicity potential, though in vitro mutagenicity tests (two indices: mutation (mouse lymphoma assay) and chromosome aberration) gave positive results, described in NTP DB (Access on May, 2006), SIDS (1996) and DFGOT (2002).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based on expert judgment in the absence of any carcinogenic effects in carcinogenicity studies in mice and rats, described in NTP TR-378 (1990).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 2 (nervous system), Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (nervous system) May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects) May cause drowsiness or dizziness (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "volunteers exposed to benzaldehyde (4.5ppm) for a minute exhibited irritation of the upper respiratory tract" (SIDS (1996)), "benzaldehyde has been reported to have local narcotic effects" (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies including "tremor" (RTECS (2006)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2. The priority rating of the referenced study is 2.

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "benzaldehyde produces depression at small doses; spasm at large doses" (CERI Hazard Data 99-21 (2000)).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 96 hours LC50=1070microg/L of the fish (Bluegill) (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003) and others.).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 66% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=1.48 (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), it was claasified into Not classified.
